author: {'steamid': '76561198114563111', 'num_games_owned': 578, 'num_reviews': 393, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1679744153}
review:
I was expecting this to be scary but it wasn't really. Just a shadow, 
loud hisses and doors slamming behind you. It was quite tense with
the time limit. I beat the game with about 2 minutes to spare. From 
start to finish it's about 30 minutes but there's some replay value
for achievements and different endings - I'll probably check them 
out. In a nutshell, the game is about escaping and finding objects
scattered around the environment to achieve this. There's stuff to
read as well. Short and sweet I guess - not every game has to be
20+ hours. I would recommend waiting for a sale. I got it for 69p
- nice. It was definitely worth that. Cheaper than a Mars bar innit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979961681', 'num_games_owned': 1195, 'num_reviews': 227, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1671348309}
review:
[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
Jump-scare Easter-egg hunt.

This game puts you into various "escape room scenarios", full of randomly generated (maybe?) sounds such as bursting light bulbs, scaring away rats, steam pipes, and other various noises meant to elicit an obvious reaction, which is both unearned, and annoying. You are mostly trying to find passwords or sequences to unlock doors, all of which is under a time limit, in the darkest fucking environment imaginable. The only option is to increas Gamma by an insane amount so you can even see anything. Normally I am not one to complain about darkness in video games, but this is just absurd.

The puzzles themselves are simple. You pick up items you think you may need, then you click on anything that gets highlighted and it automatically picks it from your inventory and uses it. There is a modicum of environmental interaction, with lots of physics objects and a few light switches here and there, but there is scant few things to do other than mindlessly click the environment and click anything that glows to see if it uses up your inventory. The items also have an immediate usage, there is not any "combining items" or creatively coming up with work-arounds or alternate solutions. What you see is what you get. And what little you can see, is not all that impressive.

I've tried playing this game twice now and I've gotten around 20 some minutes far each time until it crashed. Normally I would persist, but there is really nothing here. The graphics are barely visible, the puzzles are all sequence based, there's nothing interesting to do with any of the interactions, and there little plot that is there which is scattered about is not interesting in the slightest.

This is a bad game.

[h1]OVERALL SCORE[/h1]
Never Buy

[h1]REPLAY VALUE[/h1]
Linear

author: {'steamid': '76561198135963241', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1658259134}
review: I actually really liked the puzzles and the atmosphere. The documents in the game were also really cool. However, the first time I played it, the game crashed about five minutes in. I read a comment in the discussion section to move the anti-aliasing to either 2 or 0, which ended up working (I moved it to zero). I was able to play through one time without problems. I wanted to play the game one more time to finish up a few things I missed and ended up getting a fatal error message about 20 minutes in which crashed the game again. If the game didn't keep crashing, I'd recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002637002', 'num_games_owned': 781, 'num_reviews': 357, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1614351821}
review:
Interesting horror puzzle game where you're on a timer. You basically have 30 minutes to solve the mystery and escape before the villain returns. In some ways, it's reminiscent of good, old "D" from back in the PS1 days. However, this definitely has a very different vibe to it.

The gameplay logic in this game took some getting used to, but once I had, that wasn't a problem. The game has its flaws and shortcomings, but nothing that would stop me from recommending this for horror and puzzle enthusiasts.

100% in 3 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198429074257', 'num_games_owned': 1455, 'num_reviews': 1353, 'playtime_forever': 1640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1640, 'last_played': 1609744887}
review:
You are kidnapped by a maniac and you only have a few minutes to get out of the building - and report everything to the police.

The game in the "room escape" genre will test your reaction speed, your powers of observation and your ability to solve non-standard logical puzzles - when your life hangs in the balance.

[b]Pros:[/b][list]
[*]+ Difficulty
[*]+ Trading cards for sale
[*]+ Achievements
[*]+ Good work with sound[/list]

[b]Minuses:[/b][list]
[*]- Optimization
[*]- FPS drops
[*]- Too dark places[/list]

[b]Total:[/b]
Quite an interesting puzzle, objects have a rule to change their position a little - but the meaning of the tasks does not change from this, like the codes. Therefore, after passing it several times, you can go to earn achievements. The game is not optimized a bit, there are freezes and FPS drawdown.
The game has a story - but it is pretty much smeared on the wrists, so only those who will delve deeply into the game will appreciate it.
Game on time - pass and forget.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045061508', 'num_games_owned': 945, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1604967695}
review:
This game is constantly crashing when launched using the Steam client. Something is up with the Steam overlay that causes some games to either not launch correctly or causes them to crash while playing (I met a few games with similar issues lately and it's definitely Steams fault and not the game, I do feel bad for the game developers getting complaints). The only way to earn achievements is if you launch the game from the Steam client (I didn't get achievements running the executable directly from the installation folder, but I was able to play for 29 minutes straight without crashing). But because I cannot run the game for more than 3 minutes if the game is launched via Steam, I deem the game unplayable to full completion. 

As far as the game goes, it is not amazing but it could be a bit of fun for those who are able to play it. It is relatively short and not very difficult, but each time you launch the game the puzzles change slightly or objects are relocated to another hidden spot. So it wouldn't necessarily be boring if you wanted to replay it later for additional achievements. Assuming that you could do that without the game crashing.

Positive review because Steam is broken, not the developers fault! Someone needs to look into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043609914', 'num_games_owned': 3556, 'num_reviews': 834, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1492066454}
review:
Enki is a puzzle horror game, where you are trapped in the cellar of a serial killer and have to find a way to escape.

Story:

As stated before, in Enki you play as an unnamed person, who is trapped in the cellar of a dangerous serial killer, he has left you and will return in 30 minutes, so you have to find a way to escape as fast as you can. 

That's about all the story you get. You can collect things to learn more backstory, but I never understood how it worked and never learned more than what the game gives you. 

Graphics:

The graphics in Enki aren't that bad, but there are some problems with it. I'll start off with the good. The environments are actually quite well designed and I liked walking around and looking at things. But that's where one big issue arises. The environments are way too dark and sometimes hunting for puzzle pieces becomes a pain in the ass. There are times when items are pretty big and you will spot them easily, but sadly some of the smaller items you might miss if they end up in a hard to see spot.

Audio:

This is the games strongest suit and it helps to build a solid atmosphere and paired with the time limit that is constantly ticking down makes the game quite intense. The jumpscares aren't that loud and are far and few between and when they happen they slightly catch you off guard, I actually quite liked the audio design. 

Gameplay: 

Enki is pretty much and escape the room type deal, you have to solve puzzles and escape your environments in the 30 minute time limit you're given and some of the puzzles I actually quite liked, like looking for medals throughout the environment and translating them into a code to unlock a door. 

Also the game has multiple endings to witness so there's slight replay value, but the one thing that gives it barely any replay value is the advertised random generated puzzles each playthrough. All this feature does is change the order of puzzles and item locations and in my opinion that is not enough to warrant another playthrough. 

The only replay value comes from the different endings, but to experience them all you can do it within an hour, since once you figure out what solution each puzzle requires you can quickly wrap up a single playthrough, even with the random generated item locations.

Verdict:

This is another situation where I wish Valve would give me a neutral option for a game, I don't really despise Enki, but sadly there's not much value in this package. The story is really unimpressive, not much replay value and overall the good puzzles and creepy atmosphere are not worth it alone, since a single playthrough lasts barely 15 minutes if you know what you're doing, however on a sale, I suggest giving this game a shot.

Pros:
+ Creepy atmosphere 
+ Good puzzles

Cons:
- Random generated puzzles don't provide any replay value 
- Some locations are too dark and make spotting items hard

Final Rating:
5/10

If you liked this review please consider joining https://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog and https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews

author: {'steamid': '76561198027102438', 'num_games_owned': 1328, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1565126790}
review:
I hate ending up giving thumbs down to a game which is actually not bad at all, but that's going to be it, unfortunately.

The GOOD stuff are - I actually quite liked the graphics. The game sets a good, unsettling atmosphere which totally does the job. Puzzles are cool (the ones I've solved as I didn't even finish the game - more about that in a bit), and basically this is potentioally a good game!

BUT -
*Not sure if it's just my monitor or if that's intentional - but seems that the game is WAY TOO DARK, even with highest gamma settings, highest brightness possible, and even on Youtube videos of the game.
It ended up hurting my eyes, mostly.
*IF you've got super-eyes and you somehow see through it all, the game is actually rather short - You're actually given 30 minutes to finish it. This is not necessarily bad if it wasn't so overpriced, relatively to what it has to offer.
*Seems like they tried to put some reading material around to give some more info & story, but really - When would I even read it when I've got 30 minutes to wander and find very specific stuff among many others in complete darkness...?
The game ends up being a nice "escape-the-room" thingy. Which, again, is not bad, but does the game description truly reflect it? I think it leaves this tiny detail somewhat vague. Or perhaps I shoul've seen it coming since they've mentioned the word "escape" so many times?

Oh well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014313584', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1564196047}
review:
Unpolished and a bit nauseating. However...

This game looks good. But the graphics and movement are janky. They could use some polish. This looks like a labor of love from a developer who had no money and just wanted to share his art with the world. What it doesn't look like is an experience you can tell your friends about. It's independent and feels it. I've seen worse indy games, but this isn't going to be in anyone's favorites list.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048312377', 'num_games_owned': 1774, 'num_reviews': 332, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1532195816}
review:
A REALLY good game, really scary too sometimes. The puzzles are challenging and sometimes even change, as locations of items and certain words. The beginning room was funny, I had no idea what to do, took me at least 30 minutes to get out of that room.

The atmosphere, the sounds... If I had hair on my back, they would have punctured my shirt and even though I love it when that happens, on the other hand I don't, because I am running out of shirts.

You make one failure or you don't do it in time before your kidnapper comes back, you have to redo everything again as in a new try.

The BLOOM is maybe a bit too excessive, but I just pretend that my kidnapper gave me a thoroughly bathing with too much soap. :D

I recommend it most definately, it's an experience for both of your special senses: Fright & Wits-Under-Pressure

review: Horrible gameplay, putting a timer on an overly dark hunt and click game. They even keep the timer running on the pause screen or if you Alt/Tab to switch screens. Would be marginally better without the timer, but not by much. I uninstalled it and watched the 100% playthrough by Caretaker on YouTube, which was more enjoyable than playing this poorly conceived game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1528137241}
review:
Tags: 1PHWS - First P. Horror Walk Sim
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Grainy, Blurry, Dark. Keyfetch easteregg hunt on a 30 minute timer in small environment. Numbers and symbols puzzle annoying roadblock. 

There are not nearly enough lore items to make this game recommendable. It is mostly just boring furniture and random kleenex boxes. The more interesting Satanic books and the occasional wall painting were alright.

The other easter eggs are small drivers license and little blurbs of printed text on sheets of paper. The multiple endings are just a different newspaper front page saying what the results of your escape from the serial killer's dungeon were, which you can enhance with the police understanding the occult connection or even catching him.

There's also a small easter egg ending in which you place items on a magical altar.

Altogether it would had been alright if the game was easier to navigate, brighter, had more lore objects, had no timer, had more scripted things to make it lively. Finding nails and keys and symbols to put in symbol slots, a crucifix and the multiple locked doors is just not very engaging.

You will either be stumped or consistently get given the 30 minute game over until you trial and error your way to the exit key, then its a matter of endurance to find all the rest of the stuff, which changes spots on different playthroughs. Annoying. Resorting to a guide sorts of breaks the purpose of playing the game for yourself, or at least removes some of the enjoyment.

Removed local content permanently and hiding from library for declutter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989290281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 315, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1526336291}
review:
https://youtu.be/8oiV5b7s7mw

So overall I'm giving this game a thumbs up, but only because I got it on a sale and I would suggest you do the same. 

So the visuals are great, and the controls smooth the biggest killer is the lack of content. The game can easily be done in ten minutes once you get the layout of the very small map. The 'different' endings are nothing to write home about either. And it is also very light on horror. 

This game would have been better if you had a shorter time limit as half an hour is way to generous so removes any tension they could have built. So in its current state it is more of a good looking time filler than any thing else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123449377', 'num_games_owned': 3455, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1515730181}
review:
tl,dr; bitesized atmospheric escape-the-room with modest replayability, provided you can overlook potential crashes. 

Hedge your bets at this game giving you an hour of play, and only buy the game when it's at a price that is worth your time.

This game is poorly reviewed for three main reasons;

- The game crashes for a lot of people
- The experience doesn't match up to the exaggerated blurb on the store page
- The initial pricing strategy was far too high, taking into account the above factors

I got it for Â£0.39 - so quite frankly I was able to ride through the occasional crash. I never lost more than 15 mins of playtime and the next run was more efficient and learned. 

The game description over-emphasises the randomisation element, however I found it quite enjoyable learning where to look for what, and how to streamline a run to hit the under-10-min achievement. 

I think relying on gamers' desire to hoard achievements also lets down the masses who bought the game. The devs would have done better to have more in-game incentive for replays - even if it's just a gallery of artwork or some lore literature to peruse. I, for one, would love for them to give this concept another bash.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2304, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1514440132}
review:
[b][i]Review copy provided by developer via Curator Connect[/i][/b]

I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s a hard limit on how long a game needs to be, but there are definitely games out there that are too short. Sometimes theyâ€™re like Detention, games so good that the scant two hours you get with it simply arenâ€™t enough. Sometimes theyâ€™re like Shadowrun Returns, games that end right when it feels like they should be getting started. And then there are games like ENKI, games that donâ€™t have enough content and try to hide that fact with little tricks. Itâ€™s not even that bad of a trick, really, itâ€™s just that nothing in the game is put together well enough to earn it a pass.

Iâ€™m not real concerned about spoilers for a short puzzle game, but if you are turn back now. Youâ€™ve been unceremoniously thrown into a pit to await some terrible fate, because your killer has wandered off for exactly thirty minutes. In that time you need to find a way out of said pit and further out of peril, but a mess of locks and codes and hidden doors are going to make that tricky. If youâ€™re diligent you might also learn a bit about why the hell youâ€™ve been taken in the first place, and maybe even find some alternative solutions to your conundrum.

First of all, yes, this game is thirty minutes long. The timer starts the moment you gain control, and if it runs out you very much die. Thereâ€™s a 99% chance your first attempt at the game is going to end like that, because the puzzles and items needed for them are not going to be very apparent from the start. Every time you die you start over with elements of the puzzles randomized, so you can learn what you need to do but not memorize exactly how to do it. I died on my first run but on the second, I was able to escape after a mere fifteen minutes.

Thatâ€™s really the main caveat of ENKI, that it is extremely short by any metric. Itâ€™s also less of a puzzle game and more of one single, expansive puzzle of â€œhow do I open this doorâ€. All of your scampering around and scrounging for keys and medallions is in service of opening the one door that leads to freedom. Once you poke a bit deeper into the collectibles and puzzle out some symbolism there is an alternate ending thatâ€™s a bit more involved, but ultimately the goal is the same and it all fits neatly into a half-hour block. I personally didnâ€™t mind the time limit itself but I am certain there are folks out there prepared to be outraged at having their progress reset every thirty minutes, and I canâ€™t say I blame them in the least.

It wasnâ€™t the time limit that grated on me, but the randomization element. To keep ENKI from being purely brute-forced, aspects of the puzzles are randomized every time you play. The puzzles themselves, like a safe with a symbol keypad and an incomplete crucifix, are always the same, but the items you need are in different places and the codes are changed up. I understand the need to keep subsequent runs fresh but this is the lowest-effort method possible, and leads to situations where you know exactly what to do and what you need, but not where to find it. It adds no depth at all to the puzzle, just the padding of finding the key or crest to continue.

I can level the same criticism at the horror element, and honestly I hesitate to call this one a horror title at all. The concept of being imprisoned by a serial killer and racing against the clock is certainly terrifying, but that tension is never more than implied by the time limit. You will never at any point be in any danger aside from the ever-ticking timer, no matter how hard the game tries to convince you otherwise. Indeed, the only reason I still call it horror is because ENKI is loaded with brainless jumpscares like gas pipes leaking and doors slamming. What potential there is for the atmosphere is utterly wasted, leaving you to fit the pieces of the puzzle together with aggravating hisses and snaps in your ears.

Iâ€™m not mad at ENKI, Iâ€™m just disappointed. The hook is good, the graphics are crisp (if a little dark), and the open-ended exploration and collectible-based endings are solid foundations for a puzzle game. But instead of building a grand house of horrors upon that foundation, we get a one-room shack with a flickering light bulb. The random element does little more than frustrate, and without that subsequent runs are just retracing steps until you do everything quick enough (which isnâ€™t much of a challenge in the first place). The final nail in this coffin was when it crashed ten minutes into my third run, wiping out my progress towards a specific ending I wanted. If ENKI canâ€™t even let me play it the way itâ€™s supposed to be played, I donâ€™t see how I could ever recommend it.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

author: {'steamid': '76561198028570547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2563, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1511770317}
review:
"ENKI" ist ein First-Person-Horror Spiel.

Wir erwachen in einem kleinen Kellerraum mit einem Skelett als direkten Nachbarn. Unsere Aufgabe: zu entkommen. Und das in unter dreiÃŸig Minuten. Weshalb es genau dreiÃŸig Minuten sind, die herunterticken bleibt unklar und merkwÃ¼rdig. ImmersionsfÃ¶rdernd ist eine solche Zeitanzeige nicht gerade. Aber wie auch immer. Um zu entkommen mÃ¼ssen wir erstmal aus dem Keller klettern und dann ein paar eher simple RÃ¤tsel lÃ¶sen und SchlÃ¼ssel finden, um TÃ¼ren zu Ã¶ffnen. Aus viel mehr besteht das Spiel nicht. 

Die Wiederspielwert fÃ¤llt entgegen der Produktbeschreibung eher reichlich niedrig aus. Denn bei einem neuen Run Ã¤ndert sich so gut wie nichts, auÃŸer der Position der Items und der Symbole auf den RÃ¤tselknÃ¶pfen. Andere RÃ¤ume oder zumindest eine andere Anordnung selbiger: Fehlanzeige. Somit ist das enthaltene Gameplay eigentlich nur knapp 30 Minuten lang.

Dabei ist die dÃ¼stere AtmosphÃ¤re gar nicht so schlecht, auch die Soundkulisse geht in Ordnung. Allerdings ist das Spiel auch dunkel, verdammt dunkel und man kriegt es auch trotz Gamma-Slider nicht nennenswert heller und die Sounds wiederholen sich oft und sind im Kern denn doch nur billige Effekte.

Dennoch wÃ¤re das Spielchen ganz nett, wÃ¤ren da nicht gravierende technische Probleme. Die Optimierung ist furchtbar, framedrops kommen immer wieder vor. Und zudem neigt das Spiel zu TotalabstÃ¼rzen. Und in dem Zustand ist das Spiel nicht wirklich zu empfehlen

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
7/10 AtmosphÃ¤re
5/10 Story
6/10 Grafik
6/10 Sound
4/10 Spielmechanik
4/10 Balancing
5/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Zu wenig, um zu gefallen.

[h1][b]5/10 Gesamtwertung

author: {'steamid': '76561198310312754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1508571107}
review:
For what it is, Enki is alright. I hesitate to necessarily call it 'fun' - the multiple endings and general story are cool  however the Keys can be a real pain to find. The game is very dark in terms of lighting and the Keys are so tiny... then there is the added bonus of them potentially spawning in hard to see places - at a certain point, you might just need to restart the game and pray they appear elsewhere with another try. Also, I rarily experience motion sickness when it comes to games but found myself feeling nautious whenever commanding the character to run around corners. 

My playtime says that I put in almost four hours but really I only played two seeing as I left the game running on my computer as I messed around doing other thngs. But yeah, I purchased Enki on sale at a great price, got two hours of playtime, and the game is ultimately an interesting experience so for that I'll recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011733436', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1482089752}
review:
Man what can I say... Very nice game! The fact that items are randomized every gameplay is a lot of challenge, at first it may seem silly but from time to time you will be missing little things. The story is very criptic with a lot of depth, I may  not be able to grasp it all yet but I feel that it tells more than it shows.

The first time I played this took me the whole 30 minutes only to get out from the catacomb!

If you are into the Anunaki this will certainly appeal to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068149445', 'num_games_owned': 7083, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1477272216}
review:
Glad I paid $1 or I would feel like I was robbed. 

The game is small so I can't give much detail without it being a spoiler. That said. The first play through is kind of interesting as you have no idea what you are looking for outside of gaining entry into rooms to ultimately escape the basement. I wouldn't really call them puzzles to solve though. More like a scavenger hunt with a dying flashlight. 

If you are into completion of achievements. This game is just monotonous in my opinion. I would have probably thought much higher of this game if not for the pointless achievements that make completionist feel compelled to clock more hours beating this random spawning object scavenger hunt with the gratification of reading a different news paper article on the closing screen.
Also, for some reason, some of the achievements that you would think would trigger together, didn't. Like reading all the pages and books....not sure how i escaped the house with 5/5 on everything but didn't get these on my second play through (since the first i did the ritual versus escaping). 

Not to mention the crashing annoyances. 
The game randomly froze and I couldn't even tab off the black screen it left behind or end task it. Logging out of windows got rid of it. Then it exited 3 other times. The last being when i was waiting to complete the escape with 0:01 second on the clock...and i had 0:28 seconds and the game just decided to exit. Lastly i fell through the world once and watching it shrink in the distance as i fell into the blackness below the game world lol.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093893648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1476887482}
review:
a pretty short game, unless you are the type that goes for the achievements. lighting is rather terrible, considering you  only have 30mins to locate all the items required to get out and find as many mysteries as you can at the same time. it kinda kills the mood since you are basically running around like a mad man looking for the items.

there isn't any time for me to read the notes after failing the first time, i pretty much just speedrun it to beat the game, so be prepare to do multiple runs.

plus, it doesn't let you pause the game so have your bathroom breaks before hand. =P

scare rating 1/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198008114001', 'num_games_owned': 1044, 'num_reviews': 268, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1476698024}
review:
YES at $3 or less. NO at $10. I got it on SALE for .99 cents and was happy with the short game. 

While I wouldn't suggest this game at $10 bucks, if it's on sale for .99 cents it's a good play. Took me 2 tries and about 1.4 hours to finish looking for all the collectible items and still missed 2. 
Each time I played some items were found in different locations, but that's about it. 
You wake up being thrown in a basement hole and have to start putting items together to find your way out in 30 minutes.
Very small area, a few rooms, keys to find, misc mission items needed for escaping. Other items are collectibles and help identify WHO your crazy captor is. 

30 minutes doesn't really leave much time to try and find all the collectibles and still escape solving all the doors, locks, and mission items. So you will probaly go back and play at least once more. 
I tried the first time to find everything and ended up dying, so I had to try a second time and still missed 2 collectible items. 

For 99 seoncs, it's cheap entertainment. But NOT at $10 bucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049701098', 'num_games_owned': 3699, 'num_reviews': 832, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1513845963}
review:
Set in the dark, gruesome basement of a serial killer, ENKI is a horror title that is solely based around solving puzzles. You will have 30 minutes to figure out your escape route, and find all of the items that you need in order to do so. The game boasts a high replayability factor due to randomly generated item placement and multiple endings that depend on how much you've learned about your captor, his previous victims, and his occult interests.

The set up for Enki is fairly decent, the basement that you're locked in is creepy and has a very obvious Satanic vibe to it. There are books on demons, alchemy, and sorcery scattered throughout the area, along with cryptic symbols and notes. You have 30 minutes to gain your freedom, and to do so you must solve easy puzzles; most of them simply involve finding keys, but some require you to find other items such as sharp nails, fuses, and large circular tokens. If you happen to find the certain key that unlocks the cellar prior to the end of 30 minutes, you will have made your escape; if you fail, you will ultimately die. It's a simple concept with a simple execution, but the random item placement does make the experience different every time. Once you know what you're looking for and where it goes, the game gets a lot easier.

While the store page does talk about multiple endings, there are five, the only difference is the headline of the newspaper at the end; escaping with mild knowledge, all knowledge, no knowledge, and two deaths. There are fifteen total "collectibles", for lack of a better term, to find in order to piece together who the killer is; five drivers licenses for previous victims, five demonic books, and five pages about the murderer himself. This does add a bit more to the story, but not very much. More in-depth endings would've been welcomed.

The last time I reviewed ENKI, I completely crucified it for its abysmal optimization. Since then, the developers released an update that fixed that. I'm happy to say that on my 6700k/GTX 1080 rig, I ran at a flawless 60FPS with full graphic settings, at a 1080p resolution. I cannot say with certainty that this patch will help lower end systems, or AMD builds; my last rig was AMD and ran this game so poorly that I never got out of the 25 FPS zone, even on low settings, and my hardware was current at the time.

After a total re-evaluation, I'm happy to say that I can recommend ENKI now. Being able to actually see what you're doing in a fluid framerate really helps things, and the developer has even seemed to fix the random crashes that used to occur and totally ruin your run. The only real improvements here could be having the timer pause when you're reading documents or when the game is paused. Other than that, ENKI is a great little escape room title and escaping from the clutches of a serial killer in a timed environment does make for a rather intense gaming experience. It's sure to appeal to puzzle enthusiasts, as well as horror thrill-seekers.

[h1]Rating: [b]4.0/5.0[/b] - Excellent, highly worth playing.[/h1]
The Horror Network [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28221963/]Curator[/url] | [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thehorrornetwork]Group[/url] Click for Gore

[b]The developer offered to provide a free copy of this game for review through The Horror Network's Curation page. However, the title had already been purchased previously.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198001963942', 'num_games_owned': 817, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1502849124}
review:
I had 5 hours of playtime for steam cards only.
The game took me like 25 mins to finish it on my first try. I played it again, and it took me around 5-6 mins to beat it.
It doesn't tell you the story and what you have to do, no voice acting, unpausable, and worst of all, the FOV is so low (which you can't change it) makes it difficult to find for the items.

few things I liked are the graphics (Unreal Engine 4 awesomeness) and how the count down timer made me panic thinking that I won't make it.

but yeah, its really short and I don't think it worth $10

author: {'steamid': '76561198032043244', 'num_games_owned': 849, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1453606274}
review: I'm fairly lukewarm on this game. At it's core, this is an escape room simulator rather than an all-out scare fest. While I appreciate Enki's puzzle content and straightforward goal (gtfo before the clock ticks down), I can't reccomend it as a memorable horror experience.

review:
The game is short: 30 minutes ! Count 1h because you don't beat it the first time. And it's 10â‚¬. Heum.
But it is also weak. You don't feel the pressure, and/or the presence of the psychopath. I even though that the character we inpersonate is schizo and has locked himself there, since we feel so lonely.
So it's not scary, the puzzle are simple, the control not great. You can't configure the keys !! The game is translated in french, but you can't play it with a french keyboard, ridiculous.
Don't buy it, really.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018329330', 'num_games_owned': 622, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1444158118}
review:
I like the setting, I did like the puzzles and I even like the graphics, but the advertised "extensive randomization system" is a total joke so there is actually no real reason for playing it again and 9.99â‚¬ for 20 minutes of gameplay is clearly overpriced. On top of that comes that it has been crashing for me three times before I could finish my first game (no save feature, so I had to restart every time).

Without the crashes (that seemingly not everybody has) I would recommend it for 4,99â‚¬ or less, but for 9,99â‚¬ I would have expected more randomization or a second map.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125866172', 'num_games_owned': 1584, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1444302367}
review: ENKI is a repeatable first person horror game that relies soley on atmosphere. You awake in a small room and basically have thirty minutes to escape the house. It has a few small amnesia like "puzzles", fairly simple to decipher. Item locations as well as puzzle answers change each game play. Story is interesting enough to keep you playing until you find everything. (for me 4 times) but the game itself leaves you wanting more. It is far too short of a game and is lacking a lot of content. The atmosphere is creepy, but after your first death..you barely notice it. Certainly not worth tha full price, but would make a nice bundle game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967177146', 'num_games_owned': 530, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1446194264}
review:
Il gioco, per quanto semplice nel concetto, mi ha lasciato una piacevole sensazione, di appagamento e di sfida. Ricorda per molti versi il famoso "Purple Room" in chiave horror, con una ambientazione soffocante e ansiolitica al tempo stesso. La grafica Ã¨ ottima per un prodotto di questa fascia, ed ho molto apprezzato diversi enigmi non propio scontati.

Pollice in su per un ottimo lavoro italiano, ben adattato anche in lingua inglese.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017792082', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1516703738}
review:
I tried it when it was released and I had many performance problems, so I left it there. With the last update I tried to take it back and I have to say that the devs worked very hard on optimization. They improved A LOT the performances on lower machines and the game is perfectly playable now!
What to say about the game...The mood is cool, creepy and uncomfortable but not really scary. Graphic seems to be quite realistic and the global experience is fine. After the first run (where you probably die) the other ones will be a bit shorter because of the knoledge of the player aquired the first times. Every time you will find a different code to solve or a different spot for a key item so probably the randomization system is not so extreme but it will still challenge you. If you want to feel the experience of a escaping/surviving/creepy game this one is ready for you. It won't keep you in front of the screen for 5 hours (unless you're an achievement hunter!) but it's still a small and well crafted experience.
Give it a shot! ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198003690319', 'num_games_owned': 1069, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1442777250}
review:
Enki is a Roguelite Horror Puzzler. You've been abducted and thrown into a basement cell. Your captor has left you alone and you're on a timer to find your way out. 

The game has great atmosphere and uses real world Theology to create a mystery to you need to investigate.

Will you find the clues you're looking for and escape? Probably not, at least not the first time. Oh and the game rearranges itself everytime. 

https://youtu.be/0XltSkGZ9xE

author: {'steamid': '76561198045692513', 'num_games_owned': 1410, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1441947190}
review:
Enki is a repeatable first person horror game. Unless youâ€™re completionist, gameplay is less than 30 minutes but the story is compelling enough to allow an enjoyable second or third playthrough even. Iâ€™m intrigue about why the player character was kidnapped so I played the game about 4 times to search for documents and info about the previous survivors.

The level itself is short. We gather items such as keys, which are needed to escape the experiment-like dungeon. Items are randomly placed. The area itself doesnâ€™t change in subsequent playthroughs. Puzzles are simple because the game does give you clues for them (theyâ€™re scattered around the area.) Theyâ€™re not difficult to find. There is a time limit of 30 minutes and that might be daunting to some but I thought itâ€™s enough time to search for all the items needed to escape the place.

The story is told through texts and details on the environment. I believe the kidnapper is collecting samples because there were other people who were in the same boat as us but they died. Probably due to the not being to able to complete the tasks laid out to them. I still have no idea what the experiment is about but I know it has an occult nature to it (If the developers are reading this, please enlighten me with this information.) There are multiple endings so multiple playthroughs are encouraged.  

The â€œscare factorâ€ of the game is 4.  [On a scale of 1-10, 1 being, â€œme looking for something to scare me but couldnâ€™t find it, no matter how hard I triedâ€ and 10 being, â€œI â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ my pants, I shouldâ€™ve worn a diaperâ€] So 4 is, â€œthe game tried.â€ Ambient sounds like pipes hissing and footsteps are startling for a first run but itâ€™s not frightening. It has great atmosphere but there is no visible threat. Most of the time, I was just scaring myself. 

Graphics looks fine but itâ€™s not as optimized as I would like. My specs are GTX 970, i7-4790S, 12 GB of ramâ€¦so on and so forth. I had slowdowns in some rooms, especially when Iâ€™m looking at any kind of light source (thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve noticed, anyways.)

I will recommend the game but get it on a sale. Thatâ€™s how I feel about it. Thanks for reading.

TLDR

Pro:
  - Intriguing story
  - Multiple endings so playing the game a few times is encouraged.
  - Good Graphics
  - Great Atmosphere

Con:
  - Not scary but sometimes startling
  - Needs optimization
  - Short 

By the way, before you depart, if you have the time, check out my video of me fooling around in Enki. 

[url=https://youtu.be/c4GxS4wzPls] Enki Video [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197969859301', 'num_games_owned': 1015, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1441602828}
review: This game is extremely short (about 30 minutes) and I can't really think of anything positive to say about it. Graphics are good, I guess. It's essentially one level and about 2000 sqft of space. "Find a clue, unlock the thing". Do that about 10 times and the game is over. There is no replay value. I would not buy it again.

First time for me playing a escape room digitally. I enjoyed the game.
The game ran a bit heavy on my system but was playable after tweaking the graphics options.
I recommend this to players who love mystery and the pressure of impending doom.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983881126', 'num_games_owned': 1046, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1440271335}
review:
A random generated first-person horror experience.
What makes this game mostly interesting is the stress on the time factor.
You'll probably not get through the whole game in one single playthrough,
which is exactly the point of the game.

The forte of this game is it's very creepy and dark atmosphere as you try to find your way through the puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169311898', 'num_games_owned': 2181, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1508122426}
review:
Enki has its atmosphere spot on. To begin with anyway. After you struggle free from your incarceration in a pitch black pit, you find yourself locked in what looks like a truck stop renovated for the glory of Satan. Dingy black corridors branch off into grime encrusted rooms decorated with morbid effigies of Christ, Biblical scrawlings and several objects that point towards your surroundings being the lair of a serial killer who is utilising blood sacrifice to incarnate the Sumerian life god of the title, Enki. Very little of what you read or pick up will be of any use to you; it's up to the player to ascertain which ghastly objects are needed to progress. You'll have to work fast though; a thirty minute timer is forever counting down, even in the pause menu.
That's where the innovation ends for me. The 'repeatable experience' tag amounts to nothing more than key objects being moved to randomized locations each time you restart the game. Sometimes you'll find four objects clustered together on one desk, other times you'll have to comb the ground in the pitch black to find a rusty nail. There are six endings to track down but it feels hardly worth it when the only thing they entail is a newspaper headline.
Despite the somewhat optimistic marketing of its replay value, I wll recommend Enki for fans of the genre. It's worth a playthrough or two. Just don't expect any endgame satisfaction.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zg6B0I-FT5w

author: {'steamid': '76561198002262125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1439970942}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014594302', 'num_games_owned': 449, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1439904737}
review: Can't say I played a lot of it, but as someone who appreciates graphical quality and a somewhat unique concept for a game I must say I did enjoy it. It has flaws, for sure and it is certainly not a long game but if you are in the mood for a graphically pleasing mystery it does the trick.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071020515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1439734593}
review: This is a great game with a premisse we have never seen before. You want and should play more rooms. Yes, its a bit short but come on the production value is very high for an indie game and if you do play multiple runs you can end up playing 4 hours or so.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992473287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1524408195}
review:
I've had some serious problems with how dark the game was, but after adjusting my monitor settings I could finally get further than the first two rooms. I hope the developer adds some more options to the game that might improve performance and being able to adjust brightness would also be nice.

I can see why some people say that they didn't get scared but in my second attempt I got some really nasty jumpscares right at the start, and I think that's really good about the game, being able to get scared even though you know where to go or what to do!

I'd recommend this to any survival-horror game fan, especially because the randomization makes the game feel fresh.
The atmosphere is really good and gameplay/puzzles are interesting, making me curious but also anxious to progress further...

author: {'steamid': '76561198048974498', 'num_games_owned': 2973, 'num_reviews': 812, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1454869876}
review:
I only have one notable criticism to make of this game, and that's that the price is a little overboard.  Depending on how lucky and/or smart you are, you may actually "finish" this in under an hour or two.  But for all you penny-pinching fuddy-duddies out there, there ARE these things called Steam Sales, and they happen a number of times a year. 
 
   All that aside...WHAT A GAME!  The ATMOSPHERE!  The GRAPHICS!  The SOUND!  The SETTING!  The SCENARIO!  Enki is, essentially, a first-person adventure game in which you have thirty minutes to find your way out of a Satan-lovin' serial killer's lair, and despite the fact that there is no strict "danger" until that thirty minutes is up, the fact that the clues/objects get spread out randomly each time you play (and are often in pretty dark nooks and crannies, easy to miss the first or even second time) means that it will probably take MOST of us several efforts to find success.  

   So in theory it's very short, but the idea is that you should probably learn a little more each time about what kind of clues/objects are required to escape, and you won't just be able to bee-line it to each object and get the fuck outta Dodge by your second attempt or anything.  I personally found myself getting a little "further" every time, until I finally succeeded on my third attempt (and even then, with less than five minutes to spare).  It's certainly a tense race-against-time, even if it's low on the ever-controversial "jump-scares".  And there's plenty of achievements to get - I'm still only at 40% as of this writing - so there may well be some replayability if you're determined to get your value-for-money.
 
   Oh, and for the first time ever:  You know how a lot of post-Amnesia games have objects you can pick up and hover and rotate in front of your face, for no discernible reason other than to add a bit of "world"-y atmosphere?  For once, this actually seems like a RELEVANT MECHANIC...you'll understand when you play.  Which you should, if you're in any way interested in horror and/or adventure games.  Let's hope the devs keep going in this direction, and make a more full-length game of roughly this style and calibre.  I'll be first in line to buy it, I tell ya.  Even if it's NOT on sale.


Verdict: 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027536883', 'num_games_owned': 862, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1438463543}
review: Not scary, not challening, not fun.  They say that it is replayable, but all that means is that they annoyingly scatter the same clues to the same boring (and easy) puzzles over the small dungeon-cellar map you find yourself in.  It crashed a few times for me before I perservered in finally getting this game over and done with.  They give you 30 minutes to "escape" - it can be done in under 5 minutes. The graphics are bad. The sound is bad.  The only thing I liked about it were the pencil drawings you find scattered around the cellar.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979932327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1530650864}
review:
https://youtu.be/rLy74f7Q_JY

While admittedly not as repeatable as it claims, ENKI is still a short thrill-filled ride to escape your captors lair. I'm on the fence about recommending this, but as I have had fun while playing it for the last 3 hours, I think I'll recommend it with hesitation.

PROS

- Timed escape concept is just a lot of fun in of itself.
- Good atmosphere, I felt genuinely creeped out at times.
- Interesting jump scares that don't feel out of place in the environment.
- Multiple endings (I've recorded one so far, more to come!)

CONS

- Not as repeatable as described by developer, the only things that change are the locations of the items required to escape. Everything else (rooms, objectives, lore etc) remain exactly the same.
- When taking the not-so-random randomization, this shortens the games playability down to those 30 minutes if you're the type of gamer who dislikes repeating things over and over.
- Crashes every so often which requires you to restart from the very beginning, even if you were 1min from the end. NOTE: Recent bug fix seems to have fixed that.

Honestly, I love games like this. I'm an adventure gamer at heart and am obsessed with all things morbid, so ENKI just fits nicely in my library. This game will definitely not be for everyone though, especially when you take into consideration the length and current bugs. So your mileage may vary with this. As I said above, I recommend it because I am having fun with it and I think there are gamers out there like myself who will enjoy it too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198015378938', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1438368688}
review:
https://youtu.be/o7WPpj3w-mg

I'd recommened it BUT only if your PC can handle it. The concept and game is great, it's not so much scary as it is tense and the puzzles and multiple endings add a lot more challenge than your average horror game.

Sadly, there aren't many settings to aid performance so If your specs aren't up to scratch this game will freeze and crash.  My older GPU could not handle this game and the fps tanked on full resolution, which is a shame because the game itself is great.

review: Survival horror is my favourite genre and this game would be right up my alley if I could get through the first seven minutes without it crashing. I know this is an indy title, but that is no excuse for releasing a game with this many bugs. Unplayable and very disappointing...

author: {'steamid': '76561198068595934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1438418289}
review:
An overall intense ride, ENKI is a decently made survival horror. Sure, the graphics are amazing, but the audio is what will really get you. I believe it is more of a psychological horror rather than a jump-scare type horror. The game is only repeatable to a certain extent - once you have seen all of the endings or believe you have seen them all, you lose interest. This feeling also furthers when you solve all of the puzzles. You have 30 minutes to escape the hideout of a serial killer who also deals in rituals and summonings. In the end, this game is more of a puzzle game than a horror game, but the work put into it is good enough to deliver.

Here is my full playthrough:
SPOILER ALERT. MY VIDEO DOES INCLUDE ONE OF THE ENDINGS, I RECOMMEND PURCHASING AND EXPERIENCING THIS GAME YOURSELF. IT IS EXTREMELY SATISFYING TO SOLVE THE PUZZLES.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sjX6qxuT6ZQ

author: {'steamid': '76561198071149849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1438471642}
review:
I do recommend this game.  


Although only on the first level:

Pros:

*good graphics.
*use of Xbox 360 / Xbox One controller compatibility
*also out for the XBOX One so made 'Next Gen'
*spooky Atmosphere.
*developers put a lot of time and effort into this. making it look nice, but also immersive gameplay.
*puzzles - can see them getting harder as gameplay commences.



Cons:

*same old story.... The Devil, Jesus, Crusification, some SAW concepts too.
*not always obvious what you can pick up and what you cannot (although this could be a positive too)
*not been really scared yet, but only on the first level, expected more Jumpy moments even on the    first level.  I think Iâ€™m too impatient though.
*crashes/ freezes/ bugs  (the random gameplay idea is great and a positive, however when it crashes and you have to play over again, it's annoying because you can't just repeat what you did previously to get to where you were when the game crashed.)

Overall, I want to play more, I want to be scared, I think it will defo scare me, I'm gunna play again when it gets dark. The bugs havenâ€™t been too bad for me - compared to what Iâ€™ve heard from other people,  I do use a powerful PC so I don't know if that may be the reason;   anyway once they get that fixed, as mentioned by other people, the concept of the game is good.  I say this but the story/concept is nothing you havenâ€™t seen before and is not original enough (for me) to make it stand out from the rest... For the price it is, and the enjoyment Iâ€™ve had so far - it gets a 'YES - I do recommend'

                                                 *****************EDIT*****************
After more play time/research.  
I now know that there are no 'levels' however there are multiple ways to play/complete the game.  Having finished it, I don't think Iâ€™ll be returning to try the other different /alternative methods. 

So, in conclusion, if you have a few spare Â£ or $ and are bored, this is a great time killer, sadly nothing more.
